Chain transfer to solvent also contributes to the decrease in molecular weight.

caption_text: An isothermal gel effect (curve 6 in Fig. 10), an early run-away or an ignition are thus accompanied by substantial increases in polydispersity. In the case of dead ended run-aways, the polydispersity abruptiy levels off since the reaction is prematurely stopped by the depletion of initiator. Moderate dead endings can have disastrous consequences on the polydispersity (Figs 4,8 and 10).

caption_text: The molecular weight distributions of radicals and dead polymers at different stages of an isothermal polymerization at 80 C are plotted in Fig. 11(a) and (b). Since the radicals are reaction intermediates, their population is constantly renewed, and is not affected by the product made in the past. The radical distributions [Fig. 11(a)] thus reflect only what is currently being made in the reactor at a given distance or time.
raw_window: The molecular weight distributions of radicals and dead polymers at different stages of an isothermal polymerization at 80 C are plotted in Fig. 11(a) and (b).
Since the radicals are reaction intermediates, their population is constantly renewed, and is not affected by the product made in the past.
The radical distributions [Fig. 11(a)] thus reflect only what is currently being made in the reactor at a given distance or time.

caption_text: In contrast, the dead polymer distribution [Fig. 11(b)] embodies information of all the products made in the reactor since the very beginning of the polymerization. The major peak is not shifted signifi- cantly but the chains formed during the gel effect create a tail on the high molecular weight side of the distribution. These curves are qualitatively similar to o o, 4, C o o o w O w o.

caption_text: The radical and dead polymer populations are shifted towards the low molecular weight region due to the temperature rise [Fig. 12(a) and 12(b)]. The effect of a run-away on the molecular weight distribution is more severe than that associated with the gel effect By decomposing the initiator rapidly, a hot spot generates numerous short chains. This is in contrast to isothermal polymeriz- ations where the gel effect produces a small population of long molecules.

caption_text: The total radical and dead polymer concen- trations calculated from the continuous approxima- tion and the method of moments show perfect agree- ment even in the case of uncontrolled non-isothermal polymerizations (Fig. 13). The chain length of the radicals and dead polymer molecules produced during a run-away can be as low as 100. The application of the continuous approximation to MMA polymerization kinetics is therefore appropriate even when low mol- ecular species are involved.
